PSDR4ifwvluJYjL1SHPxUg.text: My husband and I were on vacation in London, and we had just spent all day walking around the city, we were already in the area (it's walkable from the Tower of London), and decided we had to visit a Gordon Ramsay restaurant while in London. First off, we did not have a reservation, and the place looked really nice, and since were were in comfy "tourist" clothes, I was a little nervous we would be turned away.  However to my surprise, the lovely and very nice hostess found us a table, and was very polite to us, and treated us just as if we were nicely dressed with a reservation. The look of the restaurant was very cool, sort of urban with lots of wood and metal textures.  All the staff was very good looking too, this is a trendy spot you can tell.  We got drinks and 3 courses. All were amazing, I highly recommend getting the scallops. I'm sure the menu changes, but when were were there they were topped with bacon and apples, in a carrot puree. Only reason why this is not 5 stars is b/c my entree was not so great.  I got pork belly, and for me at least the texture was a little off.However, if you want a chic date night with amazing service and great food - highly recommend checking out Bread Street Kitchen. :-)

WTwYM4XqJ8v4n8b6fMLXqw.text: I booked a table in advance for my girlfriends birthday. There's a certain amount of pressure that comes with booking a table for a birthday dinner: you kinda don't want to mess that one up by picking a place that will serve you microwave popcorn and flat coke. We arrived 45 minutes early and from that moment on the service was by far the best I've ever had in London. I was carrying flowers for my girlfriend and the staff immediately offered to put them safely away while friendly welcoming us to the restaurant. Even though we were early, they got us a table on the spot.The place itself is decorated with tremendous good taste and the tall windows all around make it feel gigantic. Our table was opposite the open kitchen but we never felt the rush of waiters running back and forward - everything was perfectly organised and if anything, it was impressive how they handle so many customers so quickly and with so much quality.Every member of the staff who attended to was was knowledgeable, fast and efficient. They made timely recommendations and were polite and friendly. The food itself was lovely. Perfect portion size, freshly made, fully flavored, great presentation. Strongly recommend the slow roasted pork with apple sauce (and top that with some delicious hand cut chips!). The desserts and coffee were also top quality, with the strawberry sorbet wrapping up a perfect meal.The price is what you expect from the place - around £40 pp. But if you want to make sure you are getting your moneys worth then this is a very safe bet. 5 stars.

78drhfNoqAOe7WeOdkXJzQ.text: Hubby and I came in here after a hard couple hours of shopping -- it was between this and ping pong and ultimately bread street won ;)We had a quick bite and drink at the bar but found the bar staff quite lovely and engaging.  I had a grey goose bloody mary (asked for it spicy and YUMMY it was!) and my hubby had a glass of tempranillo.  we had the crisps which were super good as well as the tamarind chicken wings. they were both a good light bite on our way home. I will be coming back for more when i actually have more of an appetite.

7QcNPD2s4K0AqtFEJvdFIg.text: I came in here during a quiet time and so I got excellent service.  The place is cavernous! I liked the vibe, would be perfect for a date. I was feeling fairly budget conscious so I only ordered 2 sides, both of which were very tasty. The mixed beans in particular were v good - if a tiny bit overseasoned.  The juice I ordered was labelled as 'fresh' and when I asked if it was squeezed there the waiter got a bit confused.  It's not squeezed on site, be warned - in case you thought you were getting a truly fresh dose...  Loos are clean and kind of weird looking with mesh doors.  It would be interesting to see what the place is like during the evening...  I'd return, but ideally on someone else's dime ;)

mGTpXHMTJRGMArfKZxi6sA.text: Bread Street you are rubbish. You're menu is limited and over priced, your staff is slow and you don't serve brunch on bank holiday Mondays. What is that? Seriously?Our bill arrived and a few items seemed to be marked a pound more expensive than they were listed on the menu. The menu that took us almost an hour to receive after we arrived.So many people rave about this place, and if you are looking for high end food, this is where you'll find it. It's just a little disappointing. Fois gras was tasty but average, the salmon was not memorable and the coffee was just m'eh.Blah blah blah blah blah...

hcyf_J1aO_RZzniU_FJvTQ.text: Another stop on my eating tour of London (while working of course!!!).  Initially, I was a bit put off as we seemed to be going into a large shopping mall to get to the restaurant... I had that "Emeril's at Universal Studios" flashback from a previous business trip years ago. :)I digress.  The space is beautiful if loud, the wine list is expansive and the staff is pleaseant and attentive.  For those of you who take special note of fit and finish these bathrooms are gorgeous!  As for the food, it was very well done and well presented.  Colleagues ate the Cod special and I ordered the John Dory special.  The fish was perfectly cooked and delightfully flavored.  Easy walk to St. Paul's so a good place to grab reservations if you are in that par tof the city.

D1Nil5Q7nImOvG4TtgdUeg.text: I'll preface this scathing review by saying the food I received was delicious. Tiny and expensive, but tasty nonetheless.But that cannot make up for the rest of my experience.1. No one acknowledged me when I arrived upstairs despite the restaurant having just opened and therefore being empty of patrons and abundant in staff.2. The menus were being printed so were not given to me when I arrived. So I ordered a white americano while I was waiting. A flat white arrived. My companion's black americano came with milk on the side.3. 40 minutes into my visit, I had to ask after the menu. It was still being printed.4. I ordered an 'americano with milk' and the server asked me if I was sure I didn't want a flat white. No, I didn't want a flat white. I didn't want a flat white the first time.5. The menus arrived 10 minutes later - a good 50 minutes after the restaurant's opening time. This is not an exaggeration or misremembered in any way.6. The food arrived promptly, but for some reason we received complimentary bread after we'd nearly finished our meal.7. We were left waiting. And waiting. And waiting. We finally got up to request the bill after we'd been in the restaurant for at least 2.5 hours.8. At least two things on the bill were more expensive than they were on the menu, which - may I remind you - was printed at the beginning of the day's service. We were automatically charged 12.5% for service on top of it all. Galling.Never again.

X0lbEH9Y_i7oNYgZEX8hDw.text: Went for lunch with a friend after wanting to go for ages.What was good: quick and friendly service, interesting menu and cocktails - I would recommend the tamarind chicken wingsNot so good: Not that many vegetarian options, we were placed right near the live band (in spite of pre booking) so was difficult to have a conversation.Prob go again if I'm in the area.

D6sxIiAnsT7t37QwrqIK5Q.text: Came here because we had a slightly bigger than usual party size and most of the posh-kind of restaurants only accepted party sizes of maximum 6 (or 7). :(Anyway, loved the interior and the general atmosphere of the place. The waiting staff were well-dressed, the bar looks friggin' awesome (they had to use ladders to reach some of the wine bottles) and there were microscopes (ones that you used in your high school science lab) decorating some of the tables. A really laid-back yet still classy kind of place that you can choose to dress up or down without feeling out of place. Location's perfect - somewhere in the City, close to St. Paul's and stone's throw from several high st. clothes stores. As for the food - like the amount of stars I've given - it's just A-OK. I've never had stomach for starters and am not a big fan of meat so I was pleasantly surprised by the fish choices - ordered sea trout and shared a side (mac + cheese). The sea trout was decently-cooked, nothing spectacular, and the broth was really salty so that made everything else slightly saltier than usual. The mac + cheese had a crunchier taste because of the fried onions but otherwise, it was a decent kind of mac + cheese (you really can't go wrong with mac + cheese). To get a varied and more unbiased opinion of the restaurant, I asked my friends what they thought of their meals, the one who I shared the mac + cheese with ordered sea bream said the taste was equivalent to catered hall food (which is seriously bad). another who had the cod fish said it was mediocre at best. LOL. Moral of the story, don't order the fish when you visit. :)Oh well - at least the bread served at the start was decent.

oLHnuI6neJamdOayHdNWeg.text: Great foods or the fish, the vegetarian option was 'good'. Mac cheese side dish was excellent. Ambiance and service ok so would come again.  However bringing port very cold from the fridge is a big no no!

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - London, United Kingdom

VPoq_wI0seNrzZyb5BDqpA.text: Booked last minute with a large group of friends last week as one of the only options available short notice... weren't we lucky! Great atmosphere, light and sunny upstairs. Ordered the sea bass which was amazingly tender with brown shrimp and heritage carrots. Very reasonable price, quick service - would recommend.

BsCXV4qahQCFYVQq_zgeOQ.text: Pretty good food. Loud, but good music. The steak sandwich was more a beef sandwich, with a bit of gristle (although the chef/cook may argue that the gristle was "marbling". Pretty good service. I would have given it four stars, but the restaurant is associated with Gordon Ramsay, and he's a nob. So, it loses one for that.

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - London, United Kingdom. Steak sandwich
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - London, United Kingdom. Lights and beer
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - London, United Kingdom. More lights

kaeIuwRvvtPJICIYI85oww.text: My review of this restaurant has been delayed, but there are still a few things which easily come to mind when I think of this restaurant.The service is very attentive and friendly.  My partner wanted a glass of wine and was given a good recommendation within our price range.  The mashed potato side was decadent - we ended up asking for some with our entree and another with the mains.I got the pork belly for my main, which is one of my favourites but often restaurants don't get the crackling right.  It was well done here and I would recommend it.We finished the dinner feeling full and happy.  Our share of the bill was around £100 for the two of us - we each had a starter, main and dessert and a couple of drinks each.

rvttNzFzjixk97lzZp8ZcA.text: The food was delicious but Mr. Ramsey needs to do something about the exhaust/ventilation system. I'd love to give this 4 stars, but my clothes still smell like fryer oil hours after leaving the place.

2KBWGsrgb7BdEw5067_kSA.text: This place is huge, located in an old warehouse. Its incredible. Great ambience, delicious cocktails. Highly recommend going on a Sunday so you can have the sunday roast, huge yummy portions which is nice as it is a bit pricey. The only reason I couldn't give five stars is our waiter, who was cold and may not have made eye contact once. Get rid of taking the orders on iPads, so impersonal!

LXlRTgKNFep5B78_bsPHPg.text: After arriving and relaying the info that I had a table booked for Grace, I was lead upstairs with a "right this way, Lydia."I did a mental double face palm and really really did not want to judge this place based purely on that unfortunate intro.LUCKILY FOR MR. RAMSAY, ahem...the food was fantastic.   Bread basket?  EH.  The salmon carpaccio with grapefruit and jalapeno and the poussin with chimichurri however, were flavored MARVELOUSLY.  Perfectly salted, perfectly.  And that is such a rarity these days right, with all the sodium conscious folk who then chase their bland mains with 4 pints of lager...and a kebab on the way home.Although for a Friday night it seemed quite empty (uh oh!) it was tough enough to get a table a few weeks prior.  As previous reviewers noted, the restaurant itself is an inspiring space made up of exposed steel piping, glass, and wood accents.  There was an old school naked (easy fella, just means no lampshade!) lamp next to us that I was going to steal, but alas I did not have a large enough handbag.BUT, would I come back for Cornish game hen with a mild salsa verde for 20 pounds though?  Probs not.  LO SIENTO, Gordy McGords, but I still love your crass face.

KP1cQzS_93ammPMdAO5qUQ.text: Expensive and unreasonable. Cool decor and good for business meal and can hold large groups. However they charge a £2 per head cover charge and when asked for still water they ended up charging us by the bottle, even though it came in a glass bottle that one would see restaurants use to hold tap water, not a sealed bottled water. Shocked at the extra fees they charge. Never had such an experience in London. Not worth it at all.

_iIL3hiPou_lxLPRf7jf9w.text: Let's start by saying that this space is stunning.  It is massive but well laid out.  There is a cool casual bar on the bottom floor.  There is also a bar if you enter from the mall side on the back side.  They don't serve food at that back bar but there is a cool community table.  And there are little lounges set up around.  I loved the checked floor and the cool lamps--A for design and interior decorating!  Service--well it kind of sucked.  So disappointing.  We were not well taken care of.  And these people who are supposed to be managers pass by but don't actually check in.  We felt ignored in the corner and I had to wait to get basics like salt and pepper to the table or more water.  They didn't bring us bread (even when we specifically requested it!)The food was good.  I went for the burger which was really good--although what made it soooo good was the ridiculously delicious slab of cheese that was on it.  But the presentation was horrible--just a burger sitting on a drab plate.  McDonald's presents a burger better.Friends had the meatball starter (ordinary) the fried pigs cheeks (which were surprisingly croquetas the plaice and the tuna.  They were all good.  Not blow your mind good but good.For dessert we had the chocolate tart with salted caramel ice cream.  Very good (but again not mind blowing).  The menu has lots of varied options--almost to the point of overwhelming.  My recommendation:  beef up the service and presentation!

A4jtl3g03EqqkuHK2c89VA.text: I've been trying to get my friends to venture east for brunch here for several months now, after I walked past it and saw how nice it is inside.They finally agreed last week and it was fabulous! What you see from the window is just the start. When you walk upstairs to the restaurant you're presented with a beautifully decorated environment that's reminiscent of a 1930's coffee house, or at least what I imagine one might look like.The food is great, with fresh, complimentary bread and excellent service. There's live music on Sundays that adds to the atmosphere and it's generally a fantastic experience.I'd highly recommend this place but I don't want it to get so crowded I have to queue up or book a table, so err, don't go here. Ever! (Please)! :)

WNiG2onVt-qgJsyfyyXN7g.text: Went in at a busy time without a reservation and was told by Ben(mate) he'd make room for us at a table in the bar. Great atmosphere, but loud so we decided to have drinks and apps and dinner elsewhere. Great service, we'll be back to try dinner!

nQdg9o-XWqyJVx18b15TSA.text: Bread and butter: Yum.Quinoa, pomegranate, cucumber and raisin salad - bleh to coriander/cilantro. It wasn't listed as an ingredient on the menu, so I ordered it because it sounded refreshing (which it was, minus the ridiculous amount of coriander). Ugh ruined the dish for me but I can see how it would be good. Pork belly: really crispy, hard fried (?) pork skin. The meat was tender and delicious but it was way too fatty. Excellent sauce and a potato mash of some sort. Tasty but wouldn't order again. Sides: Greens were plain but just what I needed to compliment the heavy meal. Chips were delicious but could've used more salt. Bread and butter pudding - too expensive, delicious but seemed underdone. Tasted like what you would expect bread pudding to be. Nothing particularly too inventive. It comes out in a cast iron small pan, which means the dish stays hot forever and burns your tongue. A small price I pay for tastiness? Service: So. Freaking. Slow.

QDjQ9Rqiqha68GVY4sf5Iw.text: Love the atmosphere, the food takes a while to come. There are lots of choices. I had partridge when i first came (which was the night's special at the time) which tastes ok. The brunch menu is mostly all eggs as expected! but you should try their steak and eggs..the steak was v juicy so i loved it, the chips that came with it was great too.

eGflTNuk0Qbdguo7I_gHcg.text: I booked for dinner last Saturday for 9:30 pm and went 30 minutes earlier- upon arrival (and despite what it is mentioned on their website that booking is not necessary) (and despite being half full) I was stopped for 10 minutes at front desk trying to find my booking- they tried with my first name, surname, and finally asked me if I am sure I booked in this restaurant !!!!I fished into my bag and got my cell phone to show them my booking confirmation email, but for weird reason there was no signal at all (even after 2 hours we tried to call a cab but no mobile line was available in this place)any way they allowed us in- FINALLY- apologizing about a crash down of the system at 8 pm that night!!the decoration is quite cool and quirky- love itmenu is a bit confusing, with three folded pages made of three different sections (starter, main and sides) and of course you can mix and matchthere is no chicken on the menu (Poussin is not chicken in my dictionary) and so many pigs !!I ordered the pie which was not bad (think the mince could have tasted and smelled better)our dessert order arrived (which was exceptional- best part of the night), was placed on a tray next to out table- but no one showed up to serve it until after ice cream started to melt in front of my eyes I stood up tried to grab the attention of any one who works in the place to come and put the plates in front of me I read on the site that this place costs approximately £25 per person. well, i do not know how is that applicable in reality as we spent 60 quid each (wine was an average bottle nothing fancy)  I am not impressed - although I really wanted to

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - London, United Kingdom

ipNDM6jhXICYszk97HpU9g.text: We dropped by here on Saturday afternoon hoping for some post lunch drinks and dessert, when we reached the 1st floor we noticed (from reading the menu) that there was also a cafe/pastries/snacks area on the lower ground floor, so decided to descend there as opposed to dining solo upstairs. Despite a great mix of cocktails and drinks menu on the lower level, the nibbles available downstairs were limited, pastries were no longer being served in the afternoon; disappointing, and the staff informed us that we could not order from the dessert menu upstairs - despite there being a fully functional lift which would have made whisking down a dessert from the upper kitchen a breeze.I guess they don't want to go the extra mile for customers (yet)... maybe feedback like this will eventually make a difference...the olives and manchego cheese we did try were good, as were the cheesy risotto mushroom balls. We also tried some veggie squash flatbreads which were ok, but nothing to write home about.As for the decor its nice, but all very artificial, this isn't some converted industrial space, its made to look like it is, and the faux staining on the bathroom mirrors takes things a little too far. Also the fake candle bulbs on the lower bar are incredibly bright, we were almost blinded by the light every time we glanced towards the bar vying for the staffs attention..We cant really comment on the food as what we had was effectively tapas, that being said we will return to try the food upstairs, I just hope its a better experience than our first.

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - London, United Kingdom. Flat Bread
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - London, United Kingdom. Lower Cafe/Bar Area

I5b6VM8bmwb8NbiSwvuKmA.text: Wouldn't recommend it, to be honest. The food was decent, the venue was interesting and it really tried to give modern vibe but it is nothing special.  Basic menu, small portions and not a very good price to quality ratio. They take great care so that the food looks aesthetically pleasing but the taste doesn't really live up to expectations. The staff was quite friendly and professional, that was the only highlight of the visit.

zGAm-8bnBZOty4yzRNogbw.text: Trendy but unpretentious restaurant, with well-prepared and tasty food. I'm a fan. Went with a group of about ten people. Although a pricey restaurant, the scene wasn't stuffy at all. Just a little bit loud-- not great for conversation, but luckily I wasn't in the mood for it. The menu was simple with a nice of range of options-- including veggie and seafood. I ordered the salmon ceviche and it was sooo yummy. The salmon was very thinly sliced, nicely salted, with just the right amount of citrus. It was not fishy tasting at all, but light and refreshing.  The portion was also quite big-- unless you're a very big eater, you could share this dish. For the main, I ordered the braised lamb.  It was a huge dish, really well cooked and nicely dressed.  Mashed potatoes on the side weren't memorable. FYI For halal eaters out there, the lamb is from New Zealand so you might be okay with it. Service was fine. All around solid and satisfying dining experience.

q3UHO8jRxmesLmMADQ88tA.text: Lovely place, the decoration and ambiance are very nice indeed! Who would have thought such a big restaurant was hiding above a quiet-looking bar.We didn't have a booking; but there were plenty of space to accommodate us right away. The menu is small; but I believe that is totally fine. Many seafood dishes; but also grilled meat; burgers and others. I ate the roasted cod with artichoke, some sort of vegetable mashed potato and red wine sauce. It was lovely; but I have to admit that for the price, the portions were a bit small and althought it was good; it wasn't amazing.... It is definitely a place to order a two or three meal course.(Ps: it wasn't until I read the reviews here afterwards that I found out it was a Gordon Ramsey restaurant)

z8g18VU4bNVYCaAdTqcrQg.text: Food was decent but the wait staff was rude and uninformed (namely our waiter and the hostess). First, we make reservations for same day at 4:00 (easy enough) but when we get there they tell us no kids under 12. We joked with the hostess the girls are almost 12 and we were the only group in the restaurant so she gladly sat us at the table they prepared for us. Kids don't eat much so they all ordered a side of mac and cheese. When one of the girls asked about the portion size of the mac and cheese the waiter rudely replied "I can't tell you just like I can't say how many leaves of lettuce are in a Caesar salad"! After ordering our food, we found out they do have a children's menu for 12 and younger! So which is it? If you don't allow kids 12 and under then why have a menu for kids 12 and under! Mr. Ramsey some of your wait staff need a lesson in manners and your people should know if you have a kids menu that kids 12 and under are allowed in your restaurant. Disappointed. Only getting 2 stars because the chef and his staff did a good job and were friendly otherwise it would be 1 star.

9cFhVWVkUF5wsbGP6343HA.text: what i liked: 1. The Ambiance 2. The chunky french fries I went with a party of 5 (with 3 adults and 2 children ages 11 & 13) for dinner... it definitely is not a family restaurant.... Dinner time attracts business professionals and the young adult crowd. It is a very nice space upstairs. I loved the high ceilings and openness of the entire dining area. The ambiance is absolutely perfect here and definitely impressive and has a new york feel inside, However, i was a bit disappointed with the food particularly the surf and turf isn't the best. For appetizers we ordered the carpaccio (good), scallops (good), flatbread pizza (not that great)~For Entrees we order a couple of surf and turfs (was very disappointed in the thin steaks. Not what i would have expected. I had the Duck breast which was really good but needed more cranberry sauce. The duck was fantastic but just a bit too salty for me personally. BUT...the thick cut crispy chips (french fries) were by far the BEST i've had around town. I might go back for drinks and dinner just for the ambiance. It's a really nice space.

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - London, United Kingdom. Surf & turf... the size of the steak was nice but wasnt the best steak
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - London, United Kingdom. My duck breat was awesome possum
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - London, United Kingdom. Loved the french fries~ bsst chips in town... so chunky and crispy

UrDL-ugBe0ZEWBoMtNB3pA.text: Been watching them work on this place for months, and finally made it here now that it is open. Had the scallops and the prawn and crab toast to stay. Scallops were ok, but nothing memorable. In general, I have a problem with prawns in the UK (I'm American, I am used to shrimp with some size to them), so the prawn toast was covered in these tiny little prawns and a little crab. Flavor was good, but I'll never write a good review of prawns anywhere in the UK, so I'll give it a pass.For the mains I had the pork belly and my friend had the short rib burger. The pork belly was a generous portion and was pork belly perfection... crispy crackling and tender, moist pork. My friend loved the burger, and loved it. The down note of the meal was the mac and cheese... the macaroni was way overcooked, and I could picture Gordon Ramsey going nuts if he tried it or someone served it to him.The scene is really great there too... high ceilings and huge windows. I'd recommend it, but be warned... it is not cheap.

Bis0kMJIwGZ9AOCuuw2eHw.text: The perfect pick me up for those extra early starts. It's so convenient opening at 7am but soon fills up with the Hustle and Bustle of City breakfast meetings by 8am. More importantly the food and service does not disappoint. (Visit - 21/10/2014 Breakfast)

rEqzO0n0nwGELYq77NnSug.text: * This review is only based on their bar - not having eaten there (yet) *Two weeks into my new job in London, and we get taken to a cocktail masterclass for teambuilding. Just through the invite, I knew how this would end up.This masterclass was held at the ground floor at the bar of the restaurant, and animated by 2 very talented and enthiusiastic barmen, showing us their secret tricks, and letting us try their fav' cocktails.Highlights of the evening in terms of cocktails:- 20th Century - a kind of deconstucted alcoholic lemon tart - very delicate. with a top mousse and a citric juice. Actually hard to describe but... BUT JUST TRY IT. It's one of the best boozy experiences ever- Harlem Hard Shake - okay, even if there is Jagemeister, caramel, ice cream and baileys, the mix just blends perfectly and makes a kind of nice alcoholic milk shake. Om nom nom.We were served with light pizzas and nibbles during our masterclass, which were pure delish of very simple, but fresh and good quality products.So if you're around St-Pauls and fancy a good cocktail, definitely a place to try out.

2R2c-yvPSRLSK-oiGcs07Q.text: We came here for dinner and rushed for our 6pm reservation. It was a disappointment to find that their was a problem with the kitchen therefore leaving us with a reduced menu selection. We agreed to eat anyway since we had come all this way to try a Gordon Ramsey restaurant. This was supposed to be the most casual and newest one out of all of them.Pros:Beautiful RestaurantFancy FeelNice DecorationThe soup.Average:Decent ServiceEveryone well mannered and niceFood came out in a timely matterHighchairs are great to have, but not when they are only suitable for older kids. There's no leg separation insert, so a smaller baby could just slip straight through. Good thing we brought our own portable chair for our 9 month old.Cons:The food.There were 2 meats on the menu... Lamb shank and a roasted chicken.The rest was all seafood. We tried the mullet, sea bream, soup, chicken and one more other fish. All were over cooked and under seasoned. Basically not seasoned at all.The bread was pre toasted and sitting for a long time under a heat lamp, which led to very hard bread.2 pounds per person is added to your bill just for dining in.12.5% service charge is added to your bill on top of the already included taxes and fees.Water. We didn't request anything fancy. Just regular water from refilled glass bottles. 2 pounds per bottle... 5 bottles... 10 pounds added to our bill for regular water for 6 adults! We complained and had this removed.Other notes:Something else to note is that this place is really loud. For a place that is supposed to have a nicer ambiance, it is very very loud. You can barely hear yourself talking.The food, we expected to be more impressive and frankly it was disappointing. The plating was just ok.I wouldn't recommend this place unless you aren't going for the food.

ZaKA5V8u6y_vS1OK8QsYiQ.text: One word to describe is disappointing...  I had high expectations and it does not deliver...  Have been there three times and ever-time I was disappointed!  Pricy for what you get and the atmosphere is poor...

fLkE8YCM4Jl4QwqPny42IA.text: Lovely space. Lovely brunch. Lovely atmosphere.As you enter you notice the effortless coolness of this place straightaway. Get a table on the first floor - and you'll be in a grand space with a little touch of urban. I went here for a Saturday brunch and it could not have been better for that lazy day. My king crab omelette was delicious and being a huge fan of crab I could see that they haven't added the crab to save a bad omelette - it was there - the king of the dish!My friend ordered a lobster roll and again - it was delicious. A perfect lobster roll - just slightly less expensive than at B&L just across the road.

rgKbpc1k3_rDY_lUJYR8OQ.text: We had a table for 2 on a busy Friday night, and was quite pleased with everything we had ordered. We received complimentary olive and parmesan focaccia, lightly salted, which was just fantastic.  I'm a big fan of hot buttered bread, and I can *almost* say that it didn't need the butter.. but I'm just gonna slab it on anyway. There was a special off-menu appy for the night, duck foie gras terrine with crostini, however they all ran out (and it was only 7pm!).  Slightly disappointing, but I was quite happy with the rest of my meal. To start, we had pan seared scallops (£12), and the veal carpaccio (£12.50).  I didn't get a chance to try the scallops, but my friend was quite happy with them, and they looked like they were cooked perfectly.  The carpaccio looked slightly more cooked than raw, but maybe I'm used to beef sashimi.  It was served with a quail egg, and a tuna dill pickle dressing.  The dressing was good - I sensed a bit of horseradish, but I wish it had a bit more of a kick to it .  Main course: Roast Pork Belly (£16) - cooked perfectly, crackling skin, tender meat.  Carrot + Red Onion Coleslaw (£3.50) - thought it was delicious! Though a bit heavy on the onion.  Still very good. Mac 'n Cheese (£4.50) - nice n creamy, slightly on the salty side!  It was OK, I don't think I'd order this again.  I do prefer the one at Barbecoa (J.O's restaurant across the way). 10oz Beef Sirloin (£28) - cooked perfectly, my friend ordered it medium, though I thought it was more on the medium rare side (the way I like it)!  Loved the fact that it came with a small bulb of roasted garlic and sauce on the side.  I wish I ordered this for myself instead of the pork belly!After sharing a bottle of wine, it came to around £65 each.  Bit pricey, but the food was good.  Overall, there weren't any jaw-dropping menu items; but the food is tasty, the atmosphere was nice, and the staff was very attentive.  Sure I'd come back if someone wanted to go here, but there are a slew of other great restaurants that I d like to try out before coming back to this one.A big fat bonus - I made reservations on toptable, and seems most (if not all) of their time slots give 1,000 points.  That's halfway there to a £20 food voucher :)

QRMWowofJ5wJlMwC3wfuGQ.text: Ordered: Many of the finger foods, including the Chorizo esque rolls, pizza, sliders, platter of hamsPrice: Team eventReview:Have been here before with a friend for dinner before too and mothing impressive. I think the bar upstairs (Madison) would be a place more fun to be. The selection of beers is slightly better than usual, but I have not been impressed by the quality of food. A little dissapointing, but not terrible. Overpriced, and small portions. This time, came with almost 15 people from our team from work, and I think none of us were left feeling immensely thrilled.

YN7s4TaIeOeBYgOmQkL4iQ.text: Bread Street Kitchen is a blast!My wife and I were visiting London recently and decided upon this place one evening.  As we approached Bread Street we became somewhat disoriented (being our first time in the city and that neighborhood).  I commented "Wow, that glass building over there looks awesome!"  Turns out, that was Bread Street Kitchen.The restaurant contains a downstairs bar, which we saw as soon as we walked in.  We walked up the stairs to the restaurant, and it was gorgeous.  A very modern design and surprisingly large!The wait staff was very attentive and helpful.  We were greeted by a manger halfway through our meal who just wanted to make sure everything was going well.The food was delicious at Bread Street.  We started with the tamarind chicken wings, which were spicy and delicious.I had the burger and my wife had the duck and we were both very pleased.  The meat was prepared very well and each dish was extremely flavorful.We would definitely come back!

s0I8ANkRVZasQQ5Of5Re9w.text: Best brunch in London!  This is one of those places where you savor every bite because it is so damn good. We've been here multiple times with friends visiting from the States. Our table typically includes the egg scramble and pancakes, you can't go wrong with either. To top it off, they have a do-it-yourself Bloody Mary bar.  The brunch food alone warrants 5 stars, but the wait staff is less than attentive. An added bonus is that they are kid friendly, as are most of Ramsay's more casual restaurants. We always talk about returning for dinner, but haven't followed through yet.

2GG_k8_fBWhaAt85zTo2kg.text: The BSK Burger at Bread Street Kitchen is a Gordon Ramsay creation. The patty has short rib in it and is very juicy as a result. A slice of Monterey Jack cheese is melted atop it and piled with pickles and a smoked tomato ketchup. On the bottom is a mayo lettuce slaw of sorts that gives the burger a creamy and savory texture. A soft bun that holds it all together is very neutral and allows the beef's saltiness and the ketchup's vinegar and salt to contrast with the creamy slaw. Gordon took a risk contrasting these flavors and it works quite effortlessly with top quality ingredients.

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - London, United Kingdom. BSK Burger

v7B3vjOj7sClfQKsciqWrQ.text: Amazing Restaurant right next To St. Pauls Cathedrale. Perfect Service, very friendly waitress, stunning food as well as beautiful interior. - The perfect spot for a special occasion! It Is very pricy but it's also worth it and I would recommend it to every London visitor! Thumbs Up! :-)

oMNzs7FuZ_aA2aFH8VWZdg.text: The staff is very friendly and they smile a lot :) I ordered steak sirloin. they serve it with salad and king crab. I ordered medium cooked and it was exactly as I wanted. The crab was fresh and juicy, which you can't find everywhere. However still I will give a four because the  salad and the steak was too salty. We are trying to live a healthy life, so why so much salt?The steak was a little bit expensive too but the rest of the menu is cheap.

7DLMqqZ6VK1lXuogknyHLg.text: My team and I went here for lunch, and it was a pleasant surprise. The bunch of us each ordered a starter and a main. I ordered the king crab California rolls as my starter, then the pork belly for my main. I absolutely loved the rolls. Not only was there a healthy amount of delicious crab on each of the six pieces of rolls but the also, the soya sauce dip added a perfect sesame-scented touch to the overall delight of this dish. As for the pork belly, it was solid though felt a bit too much/heavy at times. Perhaps, it would have been better if they served slightly less and instead offered more sides to go with the plate (as of now, you have to order all the sides separately). Service was good, though it did take them longer than what I would have expected for a party of ten people. Ambience was also solid -- somewhat reminiscent of Hawksmoor but a brighter version of it.Overall, a great place to try out!

a6vfpC_wqcV7fGIoL1C7oA.text: Busy place, lots of action.  Drinks are consistent but not mind blowing.   Had the tuna tartare to start.  It was nice.  Then went with the rib-eye steak which was very nice.   We saw a fight break out between the wait staff right near our table which was exciting. Not sure what happened.  The chocolate cake was also very nice.

dS_jnKZIszuHFmhnjFdc6A.text: I really loved the atmosphere and style of the restaurant. I think it will be really good for any occasion Food was as expected, good quality

QOM6Cx0XYkO5Ppk_5Yfw5A.text: Overall a very disappointing experience. Food is not what you would expect for the price and celebrity endorsement. They lie about the availability of ingredients in their cocktails and will charge you an inexplicable cover charge (we were a party of 4 and the bill came to £250). Service is also extremely lacking. Won't be returning and certainly not recommending to others. In Gordon's own words, it's not f*cking good enough.

92df6dGK4Y4pLNFS7KuJvg.text: Having recently moved to town, my wife and I were tired of rolling the dice with whatever place we ended up in and made a booking for the GR restaurant nearby for a proper dinner.  We were not disappointed.  I was a bit unsettled by walking in to find a DJ and bumping music.  Thankfully the dining room was upstairs away from all of that, though still much too loud for my taste.  Yes, I'm getting crotchety in my old age.  The restaurant was larger than I expected and I loved the open kitchen setup and the desk lamp decor throughout.  Our server came over and we got down to business with our meal.  A few starters, main, side and dessert.  Here's our lineup:  Seared Yellow fin tuna, aji amarillo pepper dressing, corn kernelsGrilled pear and endive, land cress, almonds, shaved Pecorino Romano and mustard dressingRoasted cod with crushed potatoes, artichoke, salted capers, red wine and lemon sauceDingley Dell pork chop 10ozBraised red cabbage with apples and sultanasPraline ParfaitThe salad was great and my preferred appetizer.  I loved my pork chop, though it never saw any of the pepper sauce that was supposed to arrive with it.  Didn't really need it, but I'm always curious to sample a good kitchen's offerings.  My wife really liked the cod.  On the waiter's suggestions we got the praline and it was a fantastic way to end our meal.We had a wonderful meal at Bread Street.  I will add that the DJ and club vibe, and especially the "cover charge" that's added to your bill, are unnecessary.  Maybe I'm old school, but when I go to a nice restaurant I like to be able to hear and enjoy the company I'm with.  Pumping music while I'm eating?  I can't go for that, no can do.

lEZIkxa6clmU050-wdmVBA.text: We got the Eggs Benedict with the mushroom omelet.  Both were excellent.  The hollandaise sauce was really really nice.  It wasn't as heavy as the sauces I am used to.  There are strong lemon notes.  Service was excellent.  Our bags were checked at the door.  Really great experience.

jKNOZ5LgxeZ7Ru3DWU7ZoA.text: Well, well, well... Mr. Ramsay, when was the last time you did a quality check here? So let's start from the beginning: what an odd front entrance! Huge curtains leading to a lonely bartender who directed me to take the stairs while directing a couple behind me to take the lift... I guess I should take that as a compliment! Upstairs I was greeted by a nice woman but unfortunately she had bad breath. Interestingly enough so did the waiter! Shortly after being shown my table I was provided with a couple of tiny although really good pieces of bread. Little did I know at this point that I'd be charged two frickin pounds per piece!!! At no point was this detail disclosed to me and it was only when the bill arrived that I noticed this rip off! I ordered the burger and the chips. I asked the burger to be prepared medium... Got it completely without a trace of pink plus it was dry and tasted ok at best. The chips were an even bigger disappointment, where they were uncertain whether they were fried (lots of grease on the outside) or baked (somewhat undercooked on the inside). The dessert was definitely better, with a pecan pie, cinnamon ice cream and an espresso. Service was sub par with the waiter disappearing at times. I couldn't help but notice that the two tables next to mine weren't impressed by the service either. From start to end it took roughly an hour and a half but I truly believe I could have been out of there in an hour should the waiter be a little more attentive and proactive. To end, I don't like the way the bill shows the total including the discretionary tip. Wouldn't it be more customer friendly to have the total first (without the tip?) and then another total showing the amount with the tip?...Anyway, Plane Food at Heathrow airport was great. This place? Somewhat of a letdown for me. It gets three stars because dessert was great, location and facility are amazing and the washroom is really cool! (how embarrassing that's one of the reasons but it's true!).

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - London, United Kingdom. 2 for a tiny piece of bread referred as 'cover'... Also, I wasn't asked whether I wanted it or informed about its cost.
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - London, United Kingdom. More cool stuff in the washroom.
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - London, United Kingdom. Washroom stalls are nice!

P3aivGDLvd7QCQ9UD-y-rg.text: This week, I had the impromptu pleasure of dining at one of Gordon Ramsay's restaurants.We're already onto a winner before I've even stepped inside because I am likely to support anything that angry and brilliant Scottish man does.I sat down for lunch at his very own, 'Bread Street Kitchen', situated in the heart of the City of London. (Might I add, right next to Jamie Oliver's restaurant, Barbecoa) What actually struck me the most was just the sheer size of the first floor, it is really quite vacuous, but with a rustic/art-deco-esque feel.To make sense of it, I guess you could think of it as, where Italian cuisine meets corporate London and the result is quite a unique restaurant of modern, clean-cut decor, strewn with well-placed homely-touchesI began my visit with a Cosmopolitan - whilst some may see this as too much on a Monday lunchtime, I can at least position myself as a cosmo-connoisseur as an excuse.I have to say, it was one of the best cosmos I have ever had - I just wish there was more of it! Made with Tanqueray Gin and Pierre Ferrand dry Curaçao with Blossoms raspberry syrup and fresh lemon juice; it was fruity, floral and perfectly balanced.I decided to start with a comforting bowl of Rigatoni. I can never resist this type of over sized pasta tubes, especially when it comes with aubergine (my favourite vegetable), and cheese (mozzarella and Pecorino Romano) Double cheese? Sold!The generous-size-for-a-starter was by no means beautiful, but it was beautifully simple, perfectly al dente and comforting. Remaining with the comfort food, I then tried the spiced braised lamb shank with mash potato, baby onions and orange gremolata. The meat was as tender-soft as I'd hoped (with maybe a little too much skin and fat for me) and the mash potato were buttery clouds. I enjoyed it very much, however I would say the rest of the dish actually wasn't packed with flavour, including the jus-y sauce surrounding the dish.The staff were pleasant, especially the chefs behind the counter. I would however say the waiting staff were relatively vacant; forgetting to take our drink order at the start or mis-remembering details - perhaps this is usual, perhaps they were just having a day-dreamy afternoon - either way I can just imagine Mr. Ramsay taking a characteristic melt-down at certain points of the service.I was thrilled to dine as this pleasant, bright and vibrant establishment and I would be happy to return for the comforting home food and excellent cocktails.Read the review: laurajreeves.com/2014/03…See more at: blissormiss.tumblr.com

Svip1hqFHJ2QXPVzLx4zIQ.text: Excellent avocado toast, kind of deconstructed but really nice.  And good smoothies

tVtR3ZcTUPgOvqVdWDSY4A.text: You know how sometimes when you're dining with a big group of friends and the courses are coming too efficiently and you're like "I wish things would just slow down because I'm having such a good time and there's nothing else I'd rather be doing at this moment than be here, laughing with these people and marveling at how lucky I am to have them"?This was like the opposite of that thing. Here is a factual description of what happened when I "dined" here: We arrived at 8:45 pm and left at 11 pm. At some point during the course of three hours, I consumed food. (I put "dined" in quotes because what actually happened was kind of like waiting at the Home Office in Croyden for your visa to get renewed where you know you had an appointment time but you get there and everyone' s clearly been promised the same thing and all eagerly straining to hear their number called with unrealistic expectation.)After we had all tried for an hour to make eye contact with our secret agent of a waiter (he was very good at evading our attentions), we finally managed to flag him down and was promised that our food would be ready in "2 minutes", which actually ended up being another 15 minutes. Then I ate something. Like a sausage dish? i don't really remember what it was because by this time, I had been starving for several hours. I did burn my mouth though in my eagerness.

8_Wc8Npg_MCcmMtZS2L1zA.text: BSK has a trendy atmosphere with lively music, everything from Steve Miller and Aretha Franklin to The Roots and Daft Punk. It has kind of a renovated warehouse feel to it, which is cool.Naturally, we started by sampling one of Chef Gordon Ramsay's appetizers. We decided on the Flat bread, complete with caramelized onions, taleggio cheese, cured pig's cheeks, pine nuts, basil pesto. I was surprised my wife was adventurous enough for pig cheeks, but I was also really happy. The flat bread itself was nice and crispy. There were salty overtones from the pork, but the majority of the flavor was from the pesto. It was good, though I'd hoped for better from a restaurant of this caliber.For my entree, I picked out the 10-ounce Dingley Dell Pork Chop, topped with bearnaise (the other options were pepper or a marrowbone and shallot sauce). The charcoal grill options (of which this is one) come a la carte, so I also added a side of Buttered Jersey Royal Potatoes with Spring Onions. The potatoes were nice and buttery, with just the right amount of flavor from the onions. They were a tad salty for my liking though. My pork chop was cooked perfectly, and the bearnaise was a great pairing. The fat ring was crisp and charred from the grill, and there was a nice charcoal flavor throughout. Cooking the chop bone-in made it extra juicy.For dessert, we decided to try the Blood Orange Baked Alaska. They were sadly out of blood orange sorbet, so they subbed in mango sorbet instead. It was really tasty! I'm sure the mango version packed more flavor than the blood orange would have anyway.We had eaten at Chef Ramsay's Maze Grill the night before, and in comparison Bread Street Kitchen was much snobbier all the way around (including the wait staff), which is weird since I think Maze Grill is the ritzier of the two. That being said, we both really enjoyed the meal.

qRXdfMulApNWpdRgvKiZGQ.text: Cannelloni with ricotta and spinach. Served and cooked well. Ellie loved it. I had the burger with Siracha mayonnaise and chips. Really well done the spice is perfectly matched. The staff is friendly and very nice. Find a dessert on the incredible dessert offering and dig in.

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - London, United Kingdom

S4FxM4rFOVemDzxSo13ccQ.text: The atmosphere is lively and fun, and the waitstaff is very good. The dishes seem slightly overpriced, based on how simple some of them seem to be. The burger was passable. I have to say though that the macaroni and cheese was EXCELLENT. If I eat here again, I will likely have that as my main.

Tbdhu5bHSPAbxgWCcvtwZQ.text: This place has taken me a surprisingly long time to visit despite being practically next door to where I work. I don't really feel like I've been missing out on much though.Went for lunch with a friend, her bro and their parents who were visiting from Dubai (I suspect working so close meant she decided to invite me to their family lunch before I spotted them from my window and crashed it anyway!). The Gordon Ramsay tag understandably offered some kind of insurance that she was taking them somewhere nice. After being ushered upstairs to the restaurant I was frankly stunned by the size of the place, taking a few seconds to check I wasn't looking into a mirror and yup, the place really did go on that far. I really liked the upmarket NYC bistro style buzz, and the large floor to ceiling windows let in lots of light which was fortunate as we'd happened upon that rare treasure that is... a sunny day in London! *gasp*The bread basket was pretty to look at though quite crusty (prompting some good discussion of the latest Great British Bake Off ep!). Sadly my main course was a let-down, the roasted cod being a generously thick portion of tastelessness, though I'm assured other choices were better. Fortunately my friend's dad had chosen a great light white wine (making me thankful I had no meetings on that afternoon), and dessert swung things back into tasty territory - my chocolate fondant had that sighworthy melt-in-the-middle gooeyness it's supposed to, and my friend's passionfruit tart prompted lots of yum's (though judging by the crusts flying off the plate towards the end, the pastry around the edge was a little hard to break). Her bro went for the 'Milk and Two' drink which was basically whisky-flavoured boozy milk (hmm something to sedate future little ones with?! err, just kidding...) whilst her dad was the most daring and hit the jackpot with 'The Harlem Hard Shake' - bacardi, jagermeister, salted caramel, ice cream and other good stuff. Yeah pretty sure I wouldn't have made it back to work at all if I'd gone for that!As you can probably tell desserts were the high point, but have restrained myself to 3-stars as guess I expected more in terms of the food and flavours given the Gordon Ramsay name on the door and those sorts of prices (luckily I was being treated this time wooh). Might have to come back to try the downstairs bar if I can persuade someone to buy me a drink one eve - I did spy some quirky gym horses that gave me flashbacks to school PE lessons doubling as bar benches which looked kinda cool... Meanwhile if you do find yourself in the restaurant, mind your teeth on the bread, avoid the cod and defo leave room for dessert!

gpLKa8YHxvrvFDbSGEOt1A.text: Really like this place.Ambiance:Great vibe. Extremely large, particularly for a restaurant in London. Fortunately the space is well utilised. High celings, good spacing between tables, and of course, the amount of space generally all result in a very bright, airy and cheerful environment. Reminds me a lot of ABC Kitchen in NY which is one of my favourite restaurants generally so that's a good thing.Food/Drinks:Quite a good cocktail selection, so that's always nice.Admittedly, I didn't take any gambles with the food; scallops and the pork belly got the most mentions on yelp so I had both and they did not disappoint. Scallops were absolutely divine. Perfectly cooked, really nice sear, and creamy in the middle. Could easily have eaten way more of these.Pork belly likewise was perfectly cooked, and melt-in-your-mouth good. The spiced apple sauce was the perfect complement. My one complaint was that the crackling was insanely salty. Ultimately all this meant is that I had really small bites of it and left a lot at the end, but it was a bit ridiculous and hence the star off the rating.Was too full for dessert sadly but the panna cotta and chocolate fondant were both calling out to me. My friend had the cod, and he said it was a great dish as well.Service:Multiple reviews mention slow service. I would have to agree. The wait staff are friendly and knowledgeable, albeit slightly inattentive. They took ages to come for the order, clear the food etc... That being said, it was still borderline acceptable.Overall, food is nothing too complex, but everything is really well executed. Awesome ambiance and a decent drink selection make this a must repeat for me. I imagine this would be the perfect brunch spot, so that's definitely going to be my next trip.

exBZgcNYpoGNaGHfgQt01A.text: My friend had recommended 'Burger & Lobster" located in the same street, unfortunately it was fully booked. Instead, I booked a table at Gordon Ramsay's 'Bread Street Kitchen' and we had a great experience.The following dishes were the standouts of the evening:- 'Grey Goose Le Fizz' for cocktail- 'Heritage Tomato tart' for starter- Duck breast, gravy and mashed potatoes for main-I would have ranked it a 5 star had they not over-charged our party for 1 drink, but it was quickly corrected.

XvgwL5TI_VSMCNo25ZF2Gg.text: Service here was incredibly slow and unpolished. Overall we enjoyed our food but we were quite irritated for how long it took for the food to come out and also the brash service. They were not very busy so it was disappointing that it took 45 minutes for the food to make it to the table.I cannot even remember how many times the servers did something a bit strange but it happened too frequently for sure. We were still eating our bread and without asking if they could clear our plates, they grabbed all the plates on the table and took off with them. Really bizarre experience.Spicy Scramble Scrambled eggs, chorizo, tomato, caramelised onion, Monterey Jack cheese Open King Crab Omelette Open-faced omelette of king crab, Wye Valley asparagus, shaved Pecorino cheese

YlKFDnm9-knAPdEVsjhBVw.text: I couldn't visit London without trying one of Gordon Ramsay's restaurants.  I had picked this one because it was elegant yet casual, and it was a short walk from our visit to St. Paul's Cathedral.  Had lunch here with two friends Easter weekend.  As soon as you walk in, the bar and large restaurant is just stunning; it is a bright, inviting, modern french brasserie style space.Although they were still serving brunch, I ordered a main...I can always order eggs anywhere!  I had the roasted cod with crushed potatoes, artichoke, salted capers, red wine and lemon sauce, and shared a side of broccoli with chili and ginger.  Although my main was tasty, the fish and overall dish was extremely rich.  I don't regret ordering the cod, but I generally do not prefer to have such rich, buttery entrees.  My friend ordered the trout,  and agreed that although she enjoyed it, it was very buttery.  That being said, I was on vacation, cleared my plate, and did an extra long cardio workout later that day;)  I had a glass of wine with my meal and finished with a nice latte.Service was friendly and the food served timely.  I had read other reviews and it was indeed odd that there was a "cover charge" on the bill of 2GBP per person.   Overall, a beautiful restaurant & I'm happy to have dined at this Gordon Ramsay restaurant during my visit London.  Cheers!

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - London, United Kingdom. Roasted cod

FiN099HeuPJCl-n41S3Ctg.text: Very much so-so. The lamb was described to me by the waiter as a "complete dish", while it was essentially just meat with two microscopic potatoes. You definitely will want to order a side dish.The service also leaves a lot to be desired. My dish took twice as much time to prepare as promised.Just go to Barbecoa instead, it's around the corner in the same building and it's amazingly better (see my review with pictures).

rhq-LLP4bKxJYeiXn2RGjA.text: Wooooooooooooowwww!!!!!! Sweet merciful tapeancing Jesus that beef wellington is insanely good. Donna was an amazing server and Alex helped us choose a to DIE FOR Syrah that perfectly paired with our dinner. It isn't cheap but you're not going to a Gordon Ramsay restaurant for a McDonald's happy meal. You're coming for world class dishes and great service which is EXACTLY what you'll find here. So glad we came!!

mRyKpDfWouRYD2G-gWdB3w.text: A friend was in town to visit and had wanted to try Bread Street Kitchen. New place? Hell yeah, especially when it's a Friday! The ambience was nice and the restaurant was on the 2nd floor. We arrived at 7pm and the place was half deserted. Hunmmmm..maybe it's summer, it's hot and people decided to head outdoor for drinks instead? Anyway, we were seated and began pouring over the menu. The waitress was fab and made good recommendations - she told us what's the most popular, dishes that always stay on the menu and personal favourite - you could tell that she was really passionate about her job.  The salmon tartar was good (it's my first time trying it so can't really compare to anywhere else). Main was steamed sea bream with butter. Surprisingly, it tastes really fresh, light and clean, none of those fishy bad smell. We also tried their cocktail, they don't scrimp on their alcohol so it was great! I like their food, the waitress who served us and the ambience. Well, i should have rated it a lot higher right? Yep, I was really torn, for the reasons below: 1. Mandatory £2 cover charge per person - no idea why 2. Service charge was included although optional - note how I've said that the waitress that served us was good? However the let down was the amount of time we needed to get their attention, way too long! Other than that, I would recommend going to Gordon Ramsey restaurant to try it out, it's worth a try at least! :)

ElhuUluklwxlmPXuZPt7WA.text: Great atmosphereTasty cocktail but barely any alcohol (in 2 different ones), and I usually like them lightWaitress was pushing every time she could for us to add more to our order, in a rather non pleasant wayFood was good, crumble very goodThe only reason why we left a tip, is because it was already included in the bill

fDk0qDCieF65KBOyxvzzpQ.text: We had Easter Dinner here with a few friends (both from London and from out of town) and everything was great. The venue is huge! I can definitely recommend this for groups! large enough tables, enough space so that you are neither crammed next to each other or have to worry that the table next to you hears every word you say. The cocktails and starters we had were great, they staff took very good care of us and of our guests with dietary requirements (vegans/vegetarians). 5 stars because while you can have "fancier" food in a few places in London, this has something for everyone and for a group of 10 people it was just perfect!

YBeR0a1zZuEvLYGfogEByw.text: Gordon Ramsay is a man with his fingers in a lot of pies.  So I had to try a burger that had Gordon Ramsay's finger in it... figuratively.  Bread Street Kitchen is just one of the 14 London restaurants that are part of the Gordon Ramsay Group - a group with 30 restaurants globally.Bread Street has a New York City, Great Gatsby vibe of the art deco 20s and 30s.  The tiled floors and looming ceilings surround you and the open kitchen gives it a noisy, New York feel as the waiters bustle to and fro.  The burger is a relatively simple affair: £12.50 for a short rib beef burger topped with Monterey Jack cheese, fresh veggies and Siracha mayo.The perfect proportions of the burger please the OCD in me. The burger is served in a brioche-style bun with an eggy, glossy finish that holds the perfectly-sized burger patty.  The cheese is melty and engulfs the patty and Bread Street has shown some restraint with the sauce so that it doesn't ooze all over you.  It appears they cut the lettuce down to size in a bid to make everything concentrically circular.  Call me OCD for liking that, but to me, the only thing worse than a lousy bit of beef is an under-sized patty that is swallowed up by the bun and toppings.Hand-cut chips or mash will be another £4 if you fancy a side - or Ramsay's mac 'n' cheese with garlic-roasted crumbs will be £5.50.  It's on the pricey side for such a simple burger, but it's done well and satisfies the meat-lover in me.  It doesn't try to bowl you over with elaborate fixings, rich delicate toppings or the like - it simply does the job.My final take on the burger: it's quite nice, but just that - it doesn't wow or stand out in a crowded London field.  It almost seems that it's on the menu because it has to be... It's good, not great.  According to Forbes, Ramsay's empire netted him $60 million in earnings in 2015 - not bad for a guy who started out playing football in Scotland.  Ramsay's culinary career started in the kitchen of Macro Pierre White before advancing through that of Albert Roux, Guy Savoy, Joël Robuchon, and Pierre Koffman.  Not a bad roster if you want to learn a thing or two about cooking.You can read my full review here: beeffanatic.com/2016/02/…

z9EXMAyumHny3I4nQHASPA.text: Had a fab meal here with 4 friends Lovely big area and nice decor and friendly stafffood quite expensive but nice varied menuRecommend the burger which was good! Would definitely go again but quite pricey They also have a monthly evening focused on a spirit or wine and matched with some food and an expert talks you through flavours etc which sounds brilliant!

SMoo7IF_Tmo9gZpe00zOYw.text: HOLY COW was this place packed on a weekday night! Everyone was there, a lot of people wearing work attire. I assume they just met up for dinner. Wow. So crowded, and pretty loud. If you are going for a quiet dinner, this is not your place.Got seated with my friend near the window which was kind of nice. The restaurant is BEAUTIFUL. I've been to a couple Gordon Ramsay restaurants in the US, so obviously I wanted to check this one out. Our server messed up my drink order, but it wasn't anything to complain about- he probably didn't hear me since it was so loud. Our drinks arrived after five minutes, our food after ten, so incredibly fast. My caesar salad was one of the best I've ever had. It's hard to ruin a basic salad or to make it stand out, but for whatever reason, it did. I got the side of macaroni and cheese as well, and it was good! Not the best or worst I've ever had, but I ate it all ;) It made me laugh how fast our food came out considering how busy the place was. The service was pretty good, but when it came time to pay, our guy disappeared. This happens no matter where I go. If you aren't in a rush, I would still stop by. It is decorated very well, and I love places that pay attention to detail. I would return, the menu had great options!

zqwl1TDLXjT6qakI33ppsQ.text: I was on vacation, and a large group of my friends and I grabbed brunch here. It was just as good as I can remember. Service was prompt even for a large group. I stuck with the Eggs Benedict and the bottomless bubbles for 15 pounds.  I did think that the time for ordering brunch could be extended. Yet, that may be the American writing this review!!

e8JUOsu5WrvZzeuh_JnqCA.text: Went there on a weekday night in April, albeit somewhat early for dinner, and reservations definitely weren't necessary. It started to fill up later. If you prefer a later meal, though, you might want to call it in, just in case. Our expectations for the bread were somewhat raised for a place called Bread Street Kitchen. The "complimentary" (except not so complimentary) bread was quite good, with a nice hard crust and soft crumb, although you could tell it wasn't totally freshly made. The butter was fresh and thick, yet easy to spread. Delicious scallop appetizer (baked scallops with carrot puree, treacle bacon, celery cress) - One of the best dishes of the night. The scallops were huge (maybe 5 cm/2in in diameter) and well cooked so they were lightly crisp on the edges yet soft, juicy, and delicate on the inside.Barbecue sampler (beef rump, gammon, lamb chop, pork sausage, veal kidney) with pepper sauce - Presentation was a bit plain, but everything was juicy, well-seasoned, and cooked to an appropriate temperature.We also had the crispy duck salad, which was fresh, but nothing worth writing home about. The duck was a bit dry for me.I have to compliment BSK's varied drink menu, including creative and classic cocktails, international craft beers, and over a dozen pages of wine. As a big beer fan, I especially enjoyed the Innis & Gunn (apparently one of Gordon's favorites!), Beavertown 8 Ball Rye IPA, and the Rocky Head Pale Ale (two of the hoppiest beers I've had in two days of pub-hopping in London).Good experience, a bit overpriced (especially considering the USD to GBP exchange rate), great service, and solid, if forgettable food.

fdna2GmKpXkJwQK7G9-xtg.text: Attentive waitstaff, lovely wine menu, unbalanced portions. Went for lunch with fellow Yelper Tirth and was very welcomed with a buggy which is a nice change of pace. Usually a buggy = a look of Holy shit where are we going to fit that thing?!Had a lovely rose that I'll have to try again but the portion of meat to accoutrements was absurd. I had ordered the Red wine braised feather blade, star anise carrot puree, creamed wild mushrooms. If you're wondering what feather blade is as i did, its beef. And it was succulent and fall off the bone (if there was a bone) soft. It was delicious. But just a smear of puree and a bit of mushroom is not going to take me as far as the meat. I had to order a side of mashed potato which was nice, but bland and super starchy. Felt like i had eaten some peanut butter and now was getting stuck to the roof of my mouth. Starchy bland gak on the roof of my mouth. Not the greatest. note to self: Always order a side.

OAppmKNX67L0ue6dhVHmLw.text: Amazing food and even better service! Best steak of my life. I wish more restaurants in the U.S. could follow the example of bread street kitchen. We had to wait a little longer than their norm (which we were willing to do because it was busy). We were given a complimentary appetizer, and the meal was served 15 minutes later. Apparently there was some turmoil in the kitchen, so the dessert we wanted would take a bit longer to prepare (again, we were okay with waiting). Sure enough, a complimentary dessert was brought our way. We didn't mention it to our server or anyone, but we happen to be visiting London on our honeymoon. We will definitely be making a return visit every time we come here, as our stay was definitely enhanced by Bread Street!

AOM3O-fGUqAKhkeTII2ZRw.text: I was lucky enough to be here on a snowy Sunday late morning with my wonderful friends  and lovely sisters (DDCM) We were greeted by a sweet young man who happily took our luggage and directed us to a women who took us to our table.   An immediate warm welcome and the amazing decor was very comforting..  Mimosas were soon flowing..   Except for D &M  they had coffee Our team of waiters were very attentive.  The chicken Sunday Roast was SIMPLY  SPECTACULAR!!    (I regret I did  not "take  away "the  the bit that  was left ) Topped off with a glass of wine !    ( D & M joined in ) The  entire decor ,look of the bar ,the  floors  and the  Christmas decorations a plus!   Would have been a real bonus to run into GORDON and should have entered the photo booth!!!   NEXT TIME

nfFlEwCdSE7XTfOmUc-5fw.text: I absolutely love going to Bread Street Kitchen, along with Heddon Street, Gordon Ramsay's restaurants are by far the best out there in my opinion in London.Bread Street Kitchen is located in One New Change (near St. Pauls) and is very upbeat and modern.  There are 2 entrances to this restaurant, you can either enter on street level and go through via the bar with beautiful cascading red curtains or you can go into the main shopping area and up the escalator past all the other restaurants including Jamie Oliver's 'Barbecoa' which is directly opposite! Talk about competition!.  The seating areas and main kitchen areas are very open planned and there are amazing 'green illuminated' fridges above the kitchen to store wines and champagnes, the exposed air conditioning system blends seamlessly into the ceiling and you hardly know it's there, very nice!.  The staff and waiters are very welcoming and know what's on the menu (including any specials).  I had a 12oz Rib Eye Steak with Peppercorn Sauce and Chips which were out of this world served in a little silver bucket, plus Dessert which was also very nice.   So all I can say to sum up this Restaurant is that if your a fan of Gordon Ramsay and are ever in London (Heddon Street - off Regent Street) and Bread Street Kitchen (Near St. Pauls) then treat yourself to an amazing meal and Dessert they won't let you down!

tDJSU-taqMELPvVrYbGgOA.text: Disappointed that Sunday Roast was out at 5:30pm on a Sunday night. My second choice was the cod and it was delicious. My husband ordered a burger and since he wasn't asked how the burger should be cooked, it came medium well. Kids ate free when adults order main entree. Great family restaurant. Not too thrilled about the order charge, but since the kids meal were free, the $6 order charge wasn't bad. Restaurant also has a free PhotoBooth, so that was an added bonus at he end of the night.

kf6EjUUNGs2xiJYZsi5Bvw.text: A few girlfriends and I have a monthly breakfast club, where we get up early and go to breakfast before work. ITS AMAZING!So this month we checked out Bread Street Kitchen. The restaurant to me looks like an old train station, each section has old style lamps and curtains, which I'm guessing during dinner they close to make it all a little more private. The menu is VERY basic. I struggled to find something that really sung out to me, and made me want to eat it. Which isn't what you want. I ended up with 2 poached eggs and toast. Avocado and Mushrooms, were extra, and a pricey £3 or more each. The coffee as usual was in a small mug, and I would normally order another when the food comes, but the staff did a drop and run, and never came back. I guess i can't complain for £15 a head for breakfast, BUT there are much better places to spend £15 for breakfast.

A498fIkG6WHS87C7SwGWTw.text: I've been to Bread Street Kitchen three times now (for brunches and dinner) and it has never disappointed. The dishes are simple but it's clear that they pay attention to detail. Everything was delicious. The staff were very attentive and lovely and I loved the decor and furnishings. Just to be aware: in addition to the service charge they do charge a cover charge and the price does tend to add up. I would recommend the scrambled eggs (brunch menu), Sunday roast and the sticky toffee pudding which is just divine.Would I go again: for occasions yes.

Qpkaxi39vostzImBybIWeg.text: Disappointing.The good- sushi starter was excellent- Seating.  Spacious and comfortableThe stuff to fix- My battered fish had bones.  8 in total.  -  The beef wellington.  Way too much garlic in both the filling and also the potatoes.  -  Service charge added which is OK but still stated on bill as optional so we almost gave twice.-  Staff - with such a high turnover I guess they just go through the motions.I wouldn't recommend and I wouldn't return to this venture.

79WDtgpWxDLWNPfEtAw-nw.text: A group of friends and I took an overseas trip and one of our stops was London. I was so excited to learn that there was a Gordon Ramsay restaurant near where we were staying, so we HAD to come try it out, specifically for the famous beef wellington. Man... what an incredibly disappointing experience this was for us..Downstairs is a pizza place, so make sure you go to the second floor for the actual restaurant. It was a gorgeous looking place. We ordered the beef wellington, a dry aged tomahawk steak, a couple sides, and some drinks. The wellington takes 45 minutes to make, just a quick tip, so definitely order that first. Our main server definitely wasn't the friendliest and didn't come back to retake our drink orders or anything. We had to flag down a couple other people to re-order. The food took almost an hour and a half to come out, and by the time we got it, it was cold. The steaks were so hard to cut through and tough to chew. If they were hot when they came out, we would've enjoyed it a lot more. The wellington itself was okay, I expected a lot more from it. Presentation of both was awesome though, but the quality of the meats did not reflect the price we paid for either. There are plenty of steakhouses back home in NYC that beat the quality of the steak here.For 4 of us, the total came out to almost $400 with a few drinks added. I don't think it was worth that price at all. I gave it a two star rating because a couple of the staff members were really friendly and made the experience a bit better. But other than that and being able to say I've eaten at a Gordon Ramsay restaurant, nothing really stood out or was memorable.

DAWeK3EDMkMd8gUHTguK_A.text: Bread Street Kitchen was really a fantastic experience. We were blown away with how massive it was! The decor is very nice and warm and welcoming. We actually came for their champagne brunch as a gift from a friend.The vegetarian breakfast was top notch. I always get extra excited when halloumi is included. Major points. The salmon eggs Benedict was also delicious. Our waiter was very kind and attentive, and overall we were very impressed with the entire experience.

sNb_1HQpVbc34hCCJTnxcA.text: I joined a few ladies for dinner at this Gordon Ramsay restaurant with much enthusiasm and excitement. I expected that Chef Ramsay's establishment would be well run and delicious. Bread Kitchen did not disappoint! I had the DELICIOUS superfood salad (packed with so many fresh, tasty vegetables) and the chocolate cake (perfectly oozing and not too sweet). Everything seemed prepared at a very high technical skill level and I really enjoyed it. The only thing I would say was missing was that "comfort" food feeling. This doesn't meant comfort food, I mean food that makes you feel happy and not just satisfied (this can come in a salad form too!). Again, technically everything was done to perfection. There was just that "extra" component missing to take it over the top. I applaud the restaurant but am not rushing to return. The ambiance is super cute. It has an after-work chill, yet slightly upscale, vibe. They even have a photo booth where you can snap photos and get a free photo strip! Love this. The service was impeccable. Well run establishment with very good food!

kEBKhyPdjkI3cg-r9P9F8A.text: Feel like eating a tub of salt for dinner? Oh, not really? Then don't come here.Things started off well. Our server was very friendly. Our cocktails were actually excellent, so we thought that was a good sign. We ordered the celeriac soup and the tuna tartare to start with. The soup was good. The tartare was slathered in a salty sauce that completely masked the tuna flavor rather than enhancing it. Nonetheless, it was edible. I ordered a dry aged ribeye - which happened to be the only dry aged thing they actually had despite the menu's suggestion that they maintain all kinds of different aged cuts. My husband ordered the lamb. Both of us were asked "pink or not pink?" Umm, is the rare to well done scale not a thing in the UK? Well, we both said pink and hoped for the best.Lamb arrived completely overcooked. Damn shame and waste. My steak was thin and looked like the horrible freezer steaks of my childhood. It, thankfully, was pink. However, it was INEDIBLE. The salt content made it absolutely impossible to eat. Awful meal.

37kJ1SR644zBB8IKl4tm0w.text: We ordered the burger, mac & cheese, caesar salad, and california roll. All were delicious! The service was good and facilities very clean. We had the chocolate fondant recommended to us for dessert which was amazing! Highly recommend this restaurant.

SdPfJCoYgK-AQOWIQrn89Q.text: This was my second visit to BSK and it was definitely the best. I was there alone and eating alone can be very awkward unless you have a great server. Camilla made my visit extra special - she was sweet, funny and attentive without being overbearing. The food was excellent all around. I started with the spicy tuna tartare which wasn't too spicy. The wonton chips were perfect - not greasy as they can be. My meal was the surf and turf. Steak was perfectly cooked and full of flavor. Chips were outstanding. The lobster tail was good, but my least favorite of the dish. For dessert I had the chocolate fondant with salted caramel ice cream. It was the perfect portion size. The fondant was warm and gooey. It wasn't cheap. But well worth it for a special treat before heading home to the states.

pTI9No3S1SoG29P-DO1loA.text: I was looking forward to trying out BSK as I'm a big fan of Ramsay and have enjoyed cooking many of the BSK dishes at home. The setting is very well done, well suited for more relaxed corporate lunches or dinners. I ordered the pork belly with spiced carrots and truffle mash. The dishes were well seasoned and tasted great though I was a bit disappointed with the pork - the skin wasn't as crispy as it could've been and the consistency of the meat was quite loose. Perhaps I'm just too picky! Though having cooked at home Kitchen by Mike's most excellent pork belly recipe (see 2nd pic), which includes 'pressing' overnight, I feel BSK could've done a better job. But who am I to give Ramsay tips! The staff were very attentive and I would go back again albeit to try a different dish.
