KND1sxnl48l3yjQvz4Btsg.text: I am a huge Gordon Ramsey fan so I was looking forward to experiencing this restaurant.  The decor and ambiance were great.  It was a very comfortable and relaxing setting.  For appetizers we got the Potted salt beef brisket.  It was tender and delicious.  For the main I got the Pork Belly.  It was cooked to perfection and the flavor was amazing.  For dessert I got the Toffee Pudding.  It was my first time ever trying STP and I was pleasantly surprised.  For drinks throughout the night I had a Bread Street G&T, Grapefruit Blossom and a Cappuccino.  Everything was great including the service.  I highly recommended coming here if in the area.

JDDoKMJHQL65OAWVsnaGhw.text: I visited this restaurant two days ago and When i went in, none of the waiter or waitress greeted me. After waiting in the gate for long hours without being guided to seat, i was calling out "excuse me" but they kept ignoring me. ( there were some empty tables in the restaurant) Eventually i got tired and as i was about to leave i saw one of the waiter or waitress smirking at me. I felt harassed and not respected at all at this restaurant. You guys are very rude and racist. Im korean American and i have so much more racism in england thaN in america.

4FdlE56MkuKL2k41hWCYSw.text: Went here with a friend last night for dinner. Atmosphere is great, vibe is good, interior decor is edgy. Being in St. Paul's it seems a bit out of place (would do better in a buzzier location for a Friday night) and the restaurant is way too big for its own good. Food was good. Nothing to rave about nothing to complain about. Reading the menu there was nothing that jumped out at me that I was like "I must have that" and I would NOT recommend the English Sparkling Wine we had. Desserts were very tasty. All in all, it was a good night out, but I wouldn't go back in a rush.  Overpriced for what it is.

X4lxS5Bo2ccdLjf0a8ixJQ.text: It was my family last night in London and I wanted to do something casual but nice.  I made a reservation online for 21:00 for four and was seated right when we walked in. Our table was very shaky which I asked for the server to put a wedge under with he did. Our server took a few minutes to get to us but lucky we were seated with the menus.  I already had an idea what i was going to have based off the menu i found online.  It then turns out that they were out of basically  everything i wanted from the starters Roasted Veal Carpaccio, Potted Salt Brisket & Baked Scallops. We ended up getting the Tamarind Spiced Chicken Wings & Flat Bread with Caramelised Onions. We told the server to place our starters while we figure out our mains. then the server tells me they are out of Roasted Sea Trout,  Spiced braised lamp shank,  Steamed sea beam. My brother wanted the lamb shank but couldn't get it instead got the rib eye. I ordered the pork belly, few minutes after the server left he came back to tell me they were out of the pork belly. the server took all menus off the table without asking if we wanted wine or any cocktails. So already not to a good start after everything we wanted was 86'd .  While waiting for the mains the table was unstable again which i looked for the server but he never came to check on the table so i had to get on my knees and fix the table myself. The food then came out by the manger and the assistant manager. I guess our server was to busy to be bothered.  The food was really good! We got 2 rib eyes med and med-well, lamb chops med and the pork chop. Then we shared order of mash, veg & mac & cheese. Overall the food was really great =, starters was a bit small but good. It was just service that sucked. We told the manager that we were very disappointed in the services as the only time the server came to the table to was take the order at the beginning. He told us he would look into this problem and waive the service charge. I work in the service industry and i know good service. The restaurant lost out and on over 100 pounds in drinks we were never asked if we wanted anything to drink as the server never came back to the table. We were going to get a bottle of wine and other cocktails.  All in all food is really good but really needs to work on service. Simple things like service would ruin a good thing. That is the mean reason would rate this a 3. Also by looking at the reviews below it looks like everyone agrees the service need's a lot of work. Instead of GR teaching other restaurateurs  about service he should review Bread Street.   Food was very good but lacked quality of service based on the price you pay. Oh yeah there is a 2pound per person service fee which i really don't understand.

C9Nnhcrdyf0szON1APPm2g.text: We went to the Bread St Kitchen on the day it was open to the public so as you would expect there were delays and mix ups that were quickly corrected. The waitstaff were excellent and well picked. Chef Ramsey was there the whole time we were and said hi and even served my husband his dessert that was delayed. The atmosphere was urban but relaxing. The only odd part was the bar is street level and the dinning room upstairs so we thought it wasn't open yet because the bar was empty. Too bad it isn't in New England USA so we could go again tonight. Oh I forgot to mention the food! It was excellent! And not RAW Lol!!!

D-4pu8HPeLkcaeLYQPee1w.text: Poor poor. Just another London gimmick restaurant. Full of try into fit a trend but very average. I had the short rib burger and Caesar salad. The former being very unexciting and not very good tasting. Same with the salad except also too salty! Barbacoa, the restaurant across the way, same poor bs

xRIUz2g_ZDtMMZnM9hvSmA.text: The food was really lovely with supreme quality ingredients. It lost points for having the tables much too close together. We ended up in conversation with the next table less than a foot away. The service was terrible. The food was very quick but with the wine sitting at the end of the section we frequently had empty glasses and had to call the waiter. For 3 courses, a beer, cocktail and bottle of wine, service included it came to £145.

dMGsblwdAShlXKZHA7bDOQ.text: When in London last June, we had lunch here as per a colleague's recommendation.  My husband had a flavorful cod dish, and I had a beet tart.  The tart was both sweet and tangy, with ample amounts of goat cheese.  The interior of this place has a unique warehouse feel.  This is a Gordon Ramsay restaurant although this information was not explicitly plastered throughout (which was nice).  However this aspect may be why reservations are always needed, and there are rules about how long you can linger, as detailed on the restaurant's website.

WCHIpJJY6HIFENhVgrKmBw.text: Good quality breakfast, going back there several days in a row and never been disappointed. Well priced, efficient staff, attracts a more business brunch crowd during the week. A relaxed atmosphere to start the day.

2ZKjEIUsp1Z7VGBHWsOMVw.text: This ticked the 2nd celebrity chef off of my list...only one left that I must go visit is John Besh in New Orleans (oh darn!).Bread Street Kitchen is amazing.  The venue is noisy but you expect it to be...it's an after work haven for the 'suits' from just a few short blocks (or tube ride) away.We started with the scallop appetizer...amazing.  I'd had an unfortunate scallop incident over 5 years ago (maybe more like 10?) and hadn't been able to stomach them since, but the sprinkling of treacle bacon made me give it a try...and I'm back to eating scallops!  I don't like carrots, but the carrot puree was amazing and added a divine sweetness to the scallops.  And the treacle bacon?  Well there wasn't a lot of it, but let's just say that I'm now curing my own treacle bacon on a regular basis!The burger...mmmmmm.  Tender and juicy and full of flavor.  That said, I asked for it with no sauce and got a lovely smearing of sauce on the bottom bun.  Guilty though I felt...I sent the bottom bun back and asked for a new one!  I didn't want anything to sully the food...special requests being messed up, I can deal with...to a degree!We also had the dessert which I can't remember but it was tasty...overall a wonderful shi-shi meal in London.  Just what I expected...though I wish Chef Ramsay had been there to call me a fat donkey or something!  :-)Even though their site says you don't need reservations...make one.  We sat at the bar upstairs for at least 15 minutes with no attention while we waited.  The Sous Chef was charming, but she couldn't give us drinks or whatnot...so we just had to settle for the entertainment of watching her create the art that is her food!  Not a bad deal really...and cheaper than drinks!

HVyCVuXFuS28Ar78tpgSlw.text: It was good, but it didn't measure up to the hype.  An attractive decor and very happening place.  Some of the food was fantastic and other dishes we found to be average.  We expected a little more considering that Gordon Ramsey has got his name on the place, but just like any restaurant anywhere they are bound to have their good and bad days.  Some of the staff behind the bar seemed more intent on playing around than to tending to customers.  The waitstaff was very responsive however and we still had a good time here though we found it to be excessively priced.  Worth one visit, but now we've been there and done that.

rRhyU6Ra9oemIMUXR37dgQ.text: Had a great dinner at Bread Street  Kitchen, the staff was quite friendly and knowledgeable and although not cheap, I would say that this is one of the better options for a good meal in the city. The menu is diverse and vegetarian friendly and the wine list is superb, with good bottles starting at £30. The interior design has an early 1900s industrial feel which fits the surrounding buildings and is trendy but not pretentious.

JXNVK0ids8cQcCc_dppKtA.text: Great little spot. It's more gastro pub with a Ramsay  feel. The food was really delicious. Fresh beer selection and really nice, helpful, attentive staff. Would defiantly go back.

PslpGN1LW4B6ib0KJbrB9Q.text: Came Sunday afternoon for drinks in the middle of a London walking tour.  the tour was a little dry so 5 of us snuck off to find something more exciting and stumbled across Bread Street Kitchen.  The bar itself is very spacious with lots of light.  it has a cool vibe along with allot of random features.  i.e like a viewing platform above the bar (for people watching?) and the facts that the seats on our bench were 2 x Pommel horse (think Olympic gymnastics).  the girls were very happy with their wine and i had the chance to try 3 different craft beers which is great to see in London.   on our second round we ordered some fries and they arrived with small little pots of brown sauce and ketchup...nice touch! Te fries were gone in no time at all.  not the cheapest place in the area but sometime you get what you pay for

Sf89w-J-8he46iLpgaCyhg.text: Went there on the first Saturday evening since the opening  this is the evening of truth for every restaurant. To take the conclusion first: It was a great experience!You enter via the bar and step up to the restaurant  it's huge, it's industrial, it's modern, it's vibrant. Very friendly staff  and hundreds of them!The menu is fantastic  including the wood stone where they finish various dishes. It's the kind of food, which you would expect from Gordon in such a location  here are some examples, we had:Carpaccio of Octopus: a little nothing with absolute fantastic tasteSteamed bass: perfect, what a tasteGrilled halibut: amazing, grilled to perfectionSuckling pig (in the wood oven): a real experienceOur favorite: the braised pork collar  this is unbelievable goodAnd last but not least: the hand-cut chips. For me these are the worldwide standard, how chips should be made  the best I ever had.All in all, for the 4 of us it was 180,- including drinks (some beers, no wine). Worth every penny, because you don't just eat there  you look around and you can't get enough of the flair of this location with the open kitchen.This restaurant and Jamie's Barbecoa (which sit's aside this one) are for me the future of exciting dining! Great job  could't imaging it better.One small criticism (I now it's the first week): Too many waiters. The main waitress was great, she was able to answer all questions on the food in detail. The other guys just brought drinks etc., but didn't have a clue about the menu.

NZ0lSsEFXCKOA77HYy9Lvw.text: After eating here last night and quite enjoying my night, i visited yelp to see how others enjoyed their meal, and was quite shocked by the reviews.The restaurant is a very classy but casual decor, with dark woods and mustard colored leather booths lining the grand 'cafeteria' layout of this fashionably retro restaurant. My girlfriend and i were seated at a rather awkward table, and after seeing me unconfortably try to squeeze into a seat next to my girlfriend, the hostess asked if we'd like a better table, subsequently being seated comfortably in a booth, looking upon the cooks madily dishing out gourmet food. We were promptly given bread and butter (notably delicious) and menus. Being a college student, the menu prices were quite expensive, but happy that i was in such an aromatic smelling restaurant, i decided to splurge. I got the chicken wings as a starter ( wonderful flavor, perfect amount of crunch) the cheeseburger (cheapest item on the menu, but was thick, unique, and delectable), chips ( which were wedge cut and crispy, but i had to ask for salt and ketchup as they were fairly bland) and the pineapple desert with passion fruit seeds and coconut sorbet (delicious combination of flavours). My girlfriend who is a vegetarian got the eggplant penne which i took a bite of and was happy with the amount of flavor. Overall, i had a very enjoyable night here. The service was good, (likely improved since our last reviewers) and the food was excellent. The only reason this place did not recieve 5 stars is due to the price of some of the main dishes (45 pounds for a steak?) and because i really couldnt understand a word my waitress said (speech impediment?). I would come back here when someone else is paying!

F3Ubd36RjhpdzYZp_w00mg.text: My wife and I are on vacation and after a long day at the Tower of London and she made reservations for dinner at 7 pm on Sunday.  We arrived and the place looked closed.  No it wasn't, just not that many people in there. It should have been a sign. We started with the potted brisket appetizer. Not bad and the pickled vegetables on the side were nice. For the entrees we tried to order the pork belly only to be told that they were out. How do you run out out of that dish at 7 pm?  So my wife ordered the cod with caramelized onions. After the pork belly disappointment I asked the waiter about the rib filet. He said you can get it medium rare or well done. Great, either perfect or like shoe leather. I ordered medium rare. It arrived and was, well like shoe leather. And it was only two slices that we about as thick as a piece of cardboard. For the cost it was a crazy small portion. On to the tastes...the cod was very good (and a decent size portion unlike the rib fillet) on a bed of potatoes  The rib beef gravy was quite nice as it was made with bone marrow and shallots. Again the beef was tough and wayyyy overcooked. Ok, so we are not blown away but liked the dinner, then we got our check.  On it was a optional 1£ charge for a food bank and a 2£ per person cover charge. Wait, what?  A cover charge for a Sunday night when there was maybe 25 people there. Simply crazy. I could understand a cover on busy nights but Sunday?Gordon, get here quick and fix this mess.

KLEwFoDLebocVIID48nz4Q.text: Good food (chicken wings, burger and sides) but crappy, under-resourced service considering the price point and service AND cover charge.

3gzkv5owZZzB4jtgxsB_uQ.text: I was first on opening day for Breakfast and almost the last to leave when I returned for dinner so definitely had more of a feel for the overall Bread Street Kitchen experience than most,With over 700 people booked for the first day I am glad I had the early day experience which would give a better idea how service would run under normal circumstances then what some other reviews have been based on during 'Rush Hour' Evening with over 200 Customers eating at any one timeincluding the usual first day river of papa'rat'zi reviewers and self-proclaimed 'expert' bloggers trying to make a name for themselves by trying to find criticism in every twisted perverse way they can whilst actually forgetting the food, Ambiance, Decor or the mostly good elements of service!Ok Breakfast first which someone has done an amazing Job sourcing as is literally the best of everything-For those who have had the fortune of indulging in breakfast at Planefood at T5 you will know what I'm talking about  It's the reason why since T5 has opened I have never taken a flight from any other terminal even if the cost of the flight was hundreds more! Service at breakfast was pretty much flawless considering 1st day a pretty mean feat with the place gradually filling.Onto dinner and an amazing great Value menu, The dearest item for main is a Massive Rib eye steak at £29 on par with my favourite steak haunts Hawksmoor and Goodman the difference was around £10 behind the above mentioned on price and taste ahead of a certain 'cooks' restaurant opposite. Who is meant to pride himself on the ability to source and cook a steak correctly!That was the most expensive item most were around the £15 mark my fiancée had the Sea Bass at £18 and my friend Gordon's amazing Short Rib burger one of the best I have sampled and at £11 making his starter and main less than £20!! Most of the starters are around £10, As you would expect from Ramsay establishment this gets you amazing fresh produce combined into a taste tantalising combination which excites and intrigues the palette. Carpaccio of octopus capers and black olives with saffron , Stone Bass, Avocado, horseradish and ginger, my choice was thinly sliced Lancashire beef, Barigoule vegetables, and quail's eggs  all I can say is organic orgasmic !So to sum up Dinner at an average of around £30 for 2 courses you would be hard pushed to find such value in the surrounding area and the quality and taste combination's just blow its competitors somewhere into the Thames! Wines and Champagnes they have a well-chosen and great value list , Bollinger Rose for eighty something pounds makes any celebration affordable.Then there is the restaurant itself £5m to launch it's for a reason, It simply is one of the most stunning sensational design in the city everything is reclaimed and extremely fun and funky I loved it. There are some great view points if you want to check out what's going on and seating that a lot of thought went into so that big groups are cosy 2's can be comfortable.. To Sum up A fantastic team and the best freshest produce make Bread Street Kitchen a fantastic experience, Amazing Value and undoubtedly one of Gordon's biggest Successes.

2yKiTAQB2N75tUSb-BJdCQ.text: Took my family here for dinner on a trip to London in June based on a recommendation from a business associate.  This was going to be our one "high-end" meal during our visit so we were really looking forward to the dining experience.  We had an early reservation and the place was pretty empty - of course that did not stop them from seating up right on top of another couple.  First off the wait staff seemed very green -- and rather awkward - it was just off.   We ordered drinks and my son hesitated a moment trying to decide what and if he wanted - the waiter totally missed this and just walked off without taking his order. I had ordered a premium liquor martini - it had to be the smalled martini I have ever seen!  To add insult to injury it was so watered down that it virtually had no flavor.  Even after drinking a second I felt as if I had just had two glasses of water. Usually after two martinis I am having trouble sitting up!Our appetizers arrived - forget what they were - but they were fine.  My daughter and I had ordered a salad in addition to our entree.  When our entrees arrived I mentioned that we had ordered salads and before I could say we no longer wanted them since our meal was there - the waiter said they were coming!  A minute later he plopped a salad down in front of us.  We were then faced with letting our hot meal get cold while we ate our salad or just tackle both of them.  This is what I mean about the service - it was just very inexperienced and not up to par with the image this restaurant is trying to project - and certainly not the prices that they are charging.Bottom line:  good to very good food - very small portions - very high prices.  Wait staff appears to have been on the job for about 2 days -- I could forgive it if it was just one of the staff --but for some reason we had about 3 or 4 staff at one time or another -- and they all seemed somewhat lost and stumbling over themselves.  I think maybe Gordon needs to start having one of his tantrums when he is there next.My advice - save your money  and go elsewhere - there are much better restaurants in London for the price.  It is a beautiful place though!

6koQP5oCBy0HX9tvhlVmYA.text: If you goto breadstreet thinking you will get a petrus experience forget it.was clear from start this is aimed at a different Market. It's loud and fun food is a massive surprise as there are so many interesting combinations and taste wonderful.Service is what you would expect from somewhere that seats 250, but still helpful and friendly.If you see reviews like I did saying about pigs head starter being unsightly and bad taste it's a person who has not been here as the pigs head starter looks like 4 croquet potatoes with a filling there is no animals head at all. So great place for an after work drink and some fab food, great for parties too really great atmosphere loved it

hsCgjazPrv5-VOpR5YCAoQ.text: Food was ok...service was HORRENDOUS. We were starving and ready to order quickly. Our waiter told us we could place a drink order, wait for the bread to come, and then he could come back and take our order. Oh, really? Are we serving you or are you serving us? What??Went downhill from that. Food took forever, and it wasn't even busy. We wanted to have the service taken off the bill, bit figured we may have to wait another hour if we did ask. It's another London restaurant that has too many manager types wandering around monitoring and not actually doing anything.

DDNCTVk-Go3maM8MV634tQ.text: I'm genuinely surprised by the positive reviews. I went for breakfast on a Sunday and found a good few gripes with the place.First of all I must say how stunning Bread St Kitchen is: whoever the interior designer was did a fantastic job - it's just like sitting in 60's New York. No complaints there.However, the service really let it down for me. The food is not out-of-this-world-amazing, which is unfortunate as that would have been the only thing to distract from the distinctly strange waiters. When we were first seated, the staff actually avoided coming over to us to take even the drinks orders - this on a very very quiet early Sunday morning, when there were perhaps only 2 more couples in the restaurant. I dread to think what it's like on a weekend night.When we were finally noticed and given the menus, we were told to hurry up with the order, and our waiter stood right by our table whilst we attempted to read and decide and communicate our order within 60 seconds.The (overpriced) food came swiftly but inexpicably still managed to be cold. This is when the service became even stranger - having ignored us for large stretches of time, they then wouldn't leave us alone to eat. We were asked 3 times how our food was within about 2 minutes, and without any of them bringing the sauces that we had asked for when the food arrived! Very frustrating.They also stood by our table with the credit card machine when they brought the bill, which was not only disconcerting but also very rude.On a brighter note, I must admit that the spinach was absolutely fantastic.However, I'm afraid that I don't have the patience or cash to go to this place again, no matter how lovely the interior is. It's genuinely terrible.

QWCezxyTJuZOr4HKLYqe8Q.text: Had high hopes for this spot but was largely let down. Coffee was rich and smooth and croissants were buttery and delicious, but eggs Benedict was hardly cooked (broke into a pool of clear egg) and cold upon arrival at the table. Fortunately the atmosphere and company were great. Will give it another go for dinner I suppose.

D8pOFV1ACNP5w49yY_8uwQ.text: Quick glance:+ faultless cooking+ hospitable service+ fun décor in NY deli-style- small portions- dull (to the point of awful) presentation- not value for money A friend and I came to Bread Street Kitchen for lunch on a Monday. We have pre-booked a table for 12:30pm and were promptly led upstairs to our wobbly table. Before I had a chance to say something about it, the maître d noticed and had this fixed by one of the waitresses. Soon after we ordered our drinks (but before our food), a couple of mini bread loaves arrived in a cylindrical basket with soft, melty butter. Good start so far. Our food came quickly but I was disappointed by the portion size and the presentation. I had the tuna with parsnip mash and peppercorn sauce (£19), which came with crispy slices of parsnip as decoration but I found the whole dish really brown and didn't look particularly appetising. My friend ordered the burger (£12) which arrived on its own with no flair and looked not too dissimilar to what one could get at GBK or Byron's but without the trimmings, although my friend did say it tasted nice. Presentation aside, the yellow fin tuna I had was fresh and delicious, beautifully seared on both sides although the slices were rather thin. The parsnip mash was smooth and creamy, and peppercorn sauce acceptable (although I am lucky that my other half can make a sauce that taste just as good). For the price of £50 for two at lunch (for two mains, a side, a glass of house white and an orange juice, including 12.5% 'discretionary' tip added to the bill), I thought it was expensive given the presentation and portion size. There are certainly many restaurants in and around London where you can get same quality of food but either better presentation or bigger size (or both) for that money. Overall, it is a banker's dig due to its proximity to the City of London (financial district) and therefore the high price might not be a deterrent for most. The restaurant offers good quality cooking (and some nice-looking cocktails, especially the dessert cocktails) but there are better haunts in London for good food at that price.

1e5VdxJQzoTDpIlxhP1DoA.text: I had an English breakfast here last Sunday  it came hot and freshly-prepared. Also, the plate was quite full and I couldn't eat it all. So I came out full and happy. Recommended!

2dCNYnnvIDUt2qO_Jy0oAw.text: very tardi service, definitely not what i expected from a G. Ramsay restaurant.food was ok, if not so so. certainly nothing i'll remember.great pana cotta dessert though. that's the only thing that was done right.i waited 35 minutes to get my first appetizer. not cool.i'll try another ramsay restaurant today or tomorrow but more high end. hopefully they get better with price.
